title: Homework1
text:
Data Science Questions
What do you think being a data scientist is about?

Data scientists will use computer programming/software and basic to advanced statistical methods to gather, import, interpret, and visualize data. Data scientists often will create statistical models to make predictions.

What differences/similarities do you see between data scientists and statisticians?

Statisticians are more likely to approach questions with respect to testing specific hypotheses, research methodology, and tightly controlled study designs. Most statisticians work in academic or research settings.
Data Scientists are more likely to use exploratory analysis and data mining techniques on larger and messier sets of data. There is less of a focus on methodological rigor in their analyses. Data scientists often focus on prediction and classification. Most data scientists work in industry settings.
Both roles rely on the same math and statistical foundations and are concerned with the accuracy and validity of their analyses.

How do you view yourself in relation to these two areas?

I am a professional focusing on business intelligence and am interested in a more rigorous study of statistical theory and methods while learning technical skills necessary to effectively transition to data science work.

title: Homework1
text:
Iris Dataset
Storing density() function results in object y.

y <- density(iris$Petal.Width)

Finding the class of object y.

class(y)

[1] "density"


Finding the type of object y.

typeof(y)

[1] "list"


Finding the structure of object y.

str(y)

List of 8
 $ x         : num [1:512] -0.656 -0.648 -0.64 -0.633 -0.625 ...
 $ y         : num [1:512] 0.00161 0.00178 0.00197 0.00217 0.00239 ...
 $ bw        : num 0.252
 $ n         : int 150
 $ old.coords: logi FALSE
 $ call      : language density.default(x = iris$Petal.Width)
 $ data.name : chr "iris$Petal.Width"
 $ has.na    : logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "density"


Here is a plot of the object y (with the code hidden)!
